Award.AwardTitle: REU Site Program at the National Solar Observatory
Award.AbstractNarration:
This award provides funding for a Research Experiences for Undergraduates (REU) Site at the National Solar Observatory (NSO). Eight students per year will be paired with scientists at NSO's two locations at Kitt Peak, near Tucson, AZ; and Sacramento Peak, near Sunspot, NM. The students will conduct extensive research into cutting-edge topics in solar physics, including helioseismology, solar-stellar connections, the dynamics of solar activity, space weather, and studies of the solar corona. They will also take advantage of the full suite of NSO's telescopes in both locations. Critically, the research experiences on offer to the students will prepare a new generation of scientists to use the upcoming Daniel K. Inouye Solar Telescope (DKIST), which is currently under construction in Maui, HI.

The NSO REU Site is deeply committed to ensuring that its cohort has broad representation from students at Tier 1 universities, as well from undergraduates at schools with limited research opportunities in STEM. Students will also be offered the opportunity to present their work at major national and international meetings, including the American Astronomical Society and the American Geophysical Union conferences.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Project Outcomes for the National Solar Observatory (NSO) Summer 2015 & 2016 REU Program

The 2015-2016 National Solar Observatory REU program was successful on many levels. The program was highly competitive, with 16 students being selected from a pool of 112 applicants. The program showed gender diversity, with 10 women and 6 men participating. Each summer the participants received professional development training with ethics in research workshops and by giving an end-of-summer summary talk to the science communities in Tucson, Boulder and Sunspot. Trips to nearby observatories and optics companies in addition to discussions with graduate faculty from nearby universities helped the undergraduates explore career paths for their futures.

The research projects for these students provided the main focus of their summer experience. Of our 16 students, two gave poster papers at the fall AGU meetings, three gave poster papers at the AAS Solar Physics Division meetings, two presented work at the AAS winter meetings, and one presented a poster and talk at the 2016 APS Conference for Undergraduate Women in Physics. Of our 16 students, five are co-authors on published papers resulting from their summer work; four have enrolled in graduate programs in astronomy, and one in an accelerated Masters program with a focus on middle school science education. Topics of the students’ summer research programs vary from modeling the formation heights of spectral lines in the solar atmosphere to measuring the detailed shape of observed spectral lines to understand the plasma physics in the solar atmosphere.

The REU project was evaluated by Dr. Kathy DeGioia Eastwood; she provided a formative assessment in 2015, and then a summation in 2016. In each assessment, the students were found to be enjoying their program, and they had suggestions for improvements. In all cases, these suggestions were implemented, and the 2016 program received a stronger student score than the 2015 program.
